thread.title: Spurs ranked No. 3 in ESPN power rankings
thread.title_full: Spurs ranked No. 3 in ESPN power rankings - San Antonio Express-News

author: Nick Moyle
title: Spurs ranked No. 3 in ESPN power rankings
text:
Photo: Rick Bowmer /Associated Press Image 1 of / 31 31 30. Philadelphia 76ers
2014-2015 Record : 18-64
The poster boys for hardwood ineptitude, general manager Sam Hinkie has implored his organization, and fans, to "Trust the Process." So far, the process has delivered an abundance of draft picks, and nothing resembling success. This year's No. 1 pick Jahlil Okafor does provide some actual on-court progress, though.
Photo: Rick Bowmer /Associated Press 30. Philadelphia 76ers
2014-2015 Record : 18-64
The poster boys for... Image 2 of 31 29. Portland Trail Blazers
Record: 51-31
The Trail Blazers are a perfect example of how fleeting success can be. Winners of over 50 games in each of their last two seasons, Rip City now surrounds Damian Lillard not with LaMarcus Aldridge, Wesley Matthews, Nic Batum and Robin Lopez, but Ed Davis, Noah Vonleh, Mason Plumlee and Gerald Henderson. Expect that 50 to flip sides this season.
Photo: Steve Dykes /Getty Images 29. Portland Trail Blazers
Record: 51-31
The Trail Blazers are a... Image 3 of 31 28. Los Angeles Lakers
Record: 21-61
Don't tell the Mamba, but this looks like, for what would be a third straight season, a team with no chance of competing in a loaded Western Conference. Bryant is 37 and has suffered so many setbacks and maladies in past years that he's a shell of the superstar he once was. Sharing the court with the aging former MVP are talented, but unproven young players in D'Angelo Russell, Julius Randle and Jordan Clarkson. Oh, and Roy Hibbert came to L.A., too.
Photo: MARK RALSTON, AFP / Getty Images 28. Los Angeles Lakers
Record: 21-61
Don't tell the Mamba, but this... Image 4 of 31 27. Denver Nuggets
Record: 30-52
There's not much room for optimism in the Mile High City — at least, not this season. But rookie Emmanuel Mudiay has the makings of a John Wall-lite, and Kenneth Faried is still a top-flight rebounder even if his other skills have yet to catch up.
Photo: David Zalubowski, Stf / Associated Press 27. Denver Nuggets
Record: 30-52
There's not much room for optimism... Image 5 of 31 26. Brooklyn Nets
Record: 38-44
Center Brook Lopez is still one of the most offensively gifted centers in the league, if he can stay on the floor. But beyond that? Thaddeus Young is a nice piece, but he's no star. Jarret Jack has been thrust into a starting roll with Deron Williams gone, and Andrea Bargnani is expected to provide valuable minutes off the bench. Even in the East, a playoff run seems unlikely.
Photo: Mike Stobe, Getty Images 26. Brooklyn Nets
Record: 38-44
Center Brook Lopez is still one of... Image 6 of 31 25. New York Knicks
Record: 17-65
It's sad that the Mecca of Basketball should feature two of the league's worst teams, but that looks to be the case once again. The Knicks signed Robin Lopez and Aaron Afflalo to join 'Melo in the starting lineup, but coach Derek Fisher hasn't been able to make the Triangle take hold in the Big Apple, and it's unclear if Anthony will return to his pre-injury offensive magnificence.
Photo: Elsa / Getty Images 25. New York Knicks
Record: 17-65
It's sad that the Mecca of... Image 7 of 31 24. Minnesota Timberwolves
Record: 16-66
Timberwolves fans shouldn't fret, because their team has one of the brightest futures among NBA teams. Rookie of the Year Andrew Wiggins will be joined by No. 1 pick Karl-Anthony Towns, forming, with Ricky Rubio, what could be the most tantalizing young talent base in all basketball. This season will be another struggle, but really, this year is all about growth, not the standings.
24. Minnesota Timberwolves
Record: 16-66
Timberwolves fans shouldn't... Image 8 of 31 23. Orlando Magic
Record: 25-57
Another team rich in talent but poor in the wins department, the Magic have three budding backcourt players with All-Star material embedded in their DNA. Elfrid Payton, Victor Oladipo and Mario Hezonja are tantalizing pieces on a team expected to finally make a leap this season.
Photo: Associated Press 23. Orlando Magic
Record: 25-57
Another team rich in talent but poor... Image 9 of 31 22. Phoenix Suns
Record: 39-43
A team with much promise heading into last season is now one embroiled in turmoil. The Suns' odd triple-point guard experiment proved a dismal failure. They shipped out Marcus Morris, the lesser Morris twin, and now have Markieff actively seeking to be dealt. On top of that, he was charged with felony aggravated assault back in April.
Photo: Rick Scuteri, Associated Press 22. Phoenix Suns
Record: 39-43
A team with much promise heading into... Image 10 of 31 21. Sacramento Kings
Record: 29-53
Perhaps ranked even higher in terms of team turmoil, the Kings' best player and head coach George Karl don't seem to see eye-to-eye. But Boogie Cousins is the league's best young big behind Anthony Davis, Rajon Rondo is on a comeback tour that should see him on his best behavior and Rudy Gay, despite his inconsistency, is still capable of shouldering the load when needed.
21. Sacramento Kings
Record: 29-53
Perhaps ranked even higher in... Image 11 of 31 20. Charlotte Hornets
Record: 33-49
The injury to Michael Kidd-Glichrist hurts a team that already struggled defensively, but the offseason imports should still make the Hornets a better unit. Nic Batum brings a jack-of-all-trades mentality and playoff experience and Frank Kaminsky is highly revered by owner Michael Jordan — though, that's not always a good thing .
Photo: Layne Murdoch, NBAE/Getty Images 20. Charlotte Hornets
Record: 33-49
The injury to Michael... Image 12 of 31 19. Indiana Pacers
Record: 38-44
David West and Roy Hibbert are gone, but Paul George is back, and playing...power forward? The Pacers are attempting a more small-ball oriented approach this season with their two bigs gone, but George, coming off that gruesome injury suffered in a Team USA game, isn't thrilled . Monta Ellis was signed for his ball handling and bucket-getting abilities, but his defense has always been somewhat suspect.
Photo: Darron Cummings / Associated Press 19. Indiana Pacers
Record: 38-44
David West and Roy Hibbert are gone,... Image 13 of 31 18. Dallas Mavericks
Record: 50-32
Duped by DeAndre Jordan, the Mavericks offseason was essentially a disaster. In lieu of Jordan, the Mavs will start ZaZa Pachulia at center, while Wesley Matthews and Deron Williams combine to form a brand new backcourt. Matthews is coming off a torn ACL, but if he can regain his pre-injury form, his signing could be a steal. Still, in the West, Dallas will find it hard to slither into the No. 8 seed.
Photo: Don Emmert / Getty Images 18. Dallas Mavericks
Record: 50-32
Duped by DeAndre Jordan, the... Image 14 of 31 17. Detroit Pistons
Record: 32-50
With both Josh Smith and Greg Monroe gone, Detroit's paint is now the sole property of Andre Drummond. Flanked by stellar shooters, a staple of a Stan Van Gundy offense, the Pistons are poised to compete in the East, especially if Drummond and Kentavious Caldwell-Pope make leaps.
Photo: Eric Gay, Associated Press 17. Detroit Pistons
Record: 32-50
With both Josh Smith and Greg... Image 15 of 31 16. Utah Jazz
Record: 38-44
The resurgence of Utah coincided with the departure of Enes Kanter and the fast rise of the Stifle Tower, Rudy Gobert. The loss of Dante Exum stings, but Gordon Hayward and Derrick Favors continue honing new facets of their game every offseason, and if Alec Burcks can just be competent , the Jazz can return to the playoffs for the first time since 2012.
16. Utah Jazz
Record: 38-44
The resurgence of Utah coincided with the... Image 16 of 31 15. Washington Wizards
Record: 46-36
Open up the vehicle, and the engine looks like John Wall. He's what makes this team go; the pistons, the fuel, the flow, everything. Wall and Bradley Beal form a deadly tandem, and Marcin Gortat and Nene look like they belong in a biker gang. Paul Pierce switched coasts, but Otto Porter, still just 22, is as gifted as any young small forward, it's just a matter of putting it together.
Photo: Kathy Willens /Associated Press 15. Washington Wizards
Record: 46-36
Open up the vehicle, and the... Image 17 of 31 14. Boston Celtics
Record: 40-42
Their best player is 5-foot-9 and comes off the bench, but Isaiah Thomas works like a fuse which ignites that offense anytime he enters the game. Marcus Smart and Avery Bradley are two of the best backcourt defenders in the league, and David Lee, Kelly Olynyk, Amir Johnson and Jared Sullinger form a strong frontcourt rotation. There's no superstar here, but Brad Stevens is skilled when it comes to molding lesser pieces into a greater whole.
Photo: Winslow Townson, AP Photo 14. Boston Celtics
Record: 40-42
Their best player is 5-foot-9 and... Image 18 of 31 13. Toronto Raptors
Record: 49-33
After a first-round flop, the Raptors went out and signed DeMarre Carroll. He was probably Atlanta's best player for most of the playoffs, but is he enough to push Toronto into the title conversation? The bench was almost entirely wiped clean and, with Amir Johnson gone, Patrick Patterson is now the starting power forward.
13. Toronto Raptors
Record: 49-33
After a first-round flop, the... Image 19 of 31 12. Milwaukee Bucks
Record: 41-41
The Bucks fledgling roster far exceeded expectations under Jason Kidd last season. As the No. 6 seed, the Bucks pushed Chicago to a Game 6 in the first round of the playoffs. Greg Monroe is in. Jabari Parker is back. The Greek Freak keeps getting, well, freakier (in a good way). The bench is deep and, while they still can't shoot, their overall length should make it difficult for the opposition to score much at will.
Photo: Dave Tulis, AP 12. Milwaukee Bucks
Record: 41-41
The Bucks fledgling roster far... Image 20 of 31 11. Chicago Bulls
Record: 50-32
Tom Thibodeau is out, Fred Hoiberg is in. And already, the new coach is dealing with some of Thib's old woes in the form of another Derrick Rose injury . Rose should be back for the regular-season opener, but much of what this team can accomplish will rely, not on Rose, but Jimmy Butler. Butler has one more leap left to make, and if he can, this Bulls team can make a serious run.
Photo: Charles Rex Arbogast /Associated Press 11. Chicago Bulls
Record: 50-32
Tom Thibodeau is out, Fred Hoiberg is... Image 21 of 31 10. Miami Heat
Record: 37-45
A team loaded with talent, but burdened by even more questions. Was Hassan Whiteside an ephemeral flash of basketball brilliance, or something more? Will Chris Bosh return fully healthy? Can Dwayne Wade stay healthy? How will the Goran Dragic-Wade-Luol Deng-Bosh-Whiteside lineup coexist? With Erik Spoelstra at the helm, it's possible, but chances are this team won't become an immediate sensation. Then again, neither did the " Heatles ."
Photo: Chris Young, Associated Press 10. Miami Heat
Record: 37-45
A team loaded with talent, but burdened... Image 22 of 31 9. Atlanta Hawks
Record: 60-22
DeMarre Carroll, such a key factor in the Hawk's shocking success, is North of the border, but Atlanta did well to replace him with Tiago Splitter and Tim Hardaway Jr. Hardaway is no Carroll, but he's young, and should benefit from the tutelage of coach Mike Budenholzer. Kyle Korver and Thabo Sefolosha should be back near the beginning of the regular-season to join Jeff Teague, Paul Millsap and Al Horford in a well-rounded starting lineup.
Photo: R Brent Smith, Associated Press 9. Atlanta Hawks
Record: 60-22
DeMarre Carroll, such a key factor in... Image 23 of 31 8. New Orleans Pelicans
Record: 45-37
It's easy to forget, because the Pellies were swept, how much of a force Anthony Davis was against the Warriors in his first playoff series. At just 22 years old, the "Brow" may already be the best basketball player in the world, and he's yet to reach his pinnacle. LeBron may still claim status as King, but there's a worthy heir with a massive shadow looming in the wings.
Photo: Dan McCarney 8. New Orleans Pelicans
Record: 45-37
It's easy to forget, because... Image 24 of 31 7. Memphis Grizzlies
Record: 55-27
Marc Gasol nixed the extravagant bidding war his contemporaries enjoy in exchange for a quick, quiet signing in the city he calls home. The Grizzlies will have a difficult time leading their campaign through the treacherous West, but their physical style of play is something no team hopes to see come playoff time. Remember, they pushed the Warriors harder than any team.
7. Memphis Grizzlies
Record: 55-27
Marc Gasol nixed the extravagant... Image 25 of 31 6. Houston Rockets
Record: 56-26
People love to hate the Rockets, but they won't care, as long as they keep tallying wins. If Ty Lawson can get his head right, he could form, with James Harden, a backcourt to match, or at least battle, the one in Oakland. Dwight Howard, despite his putrid free throw shooting, still controls games with his defensive brilliance, and Donatas Motiejunas has the makings of an excellent complementary piece, if only he can stay healthy.
Photo: Scott Halleran /Getty Images 6. Houston Rockets
Record: 56-26
People love to hate the Rockets, but... Image 26 of 31 5. Oklahoma City Thunder
Record: 45-37
The Russell Westbrook show finally had a full-opening last season, and it didn't disappoint. Yet, despite the triple-doubles and mean mugs and wrathful dunks, the Thunder missed the playoffs. Success in OKC relies on Kevin Durant and his — hopefully — healed foot.
Photo: Alonzo Adams, Alonzo Adams-USA TODAY Sports 5. Oklahoma City Thunder
Record: 45-37
The Russell Westbrook show... Image 27 of 31 4. Los Angeles Clippers
Record: 56-26
The DeAndre Jordan saga hijacked the Summer, just like his teammates hijacked him after he had verbally agreed to become a Maverick. The bench was a problem last season, but, if they can coexist, the depth provided by Paul Pierce, Josh Smith and Lance Stephenson should bolster a starting lineup featuring two perennial All-NBAers in Chris Paul and Blake Griffin.
Photo: Jae C. Hong, STF / Associated Press 4. Los Angeles Clippers
Record: 56-26
The DeAndre Jordan saga... Image 28 of 31 3. San Antonio Spurs
Record: 55-27
Like cockroaches and Twinkies and Madonna and everything else that can supposedly survive the end of times, the Spurs simply won't die. They won the LaMarcus Aldridge Sweepstakes. David West eschewed millions to chase Larry O'Brien. And, on top of it, the old gang is bang together yet again, maybe for one last ride into that beautiful Texas sunset.
Photo: Chris Covatta /Getty Images 3. San Antonio Spurs
Record: 55-27
Like cockroaches and Twinkies and... Image 29 of 31 2. Cleveland Cavaliers
Record: 53-29
Injuries derailed what may have been Cleveland's first professional championship since 1964. A healthy LeBron, Kyrie Irving and Kevin Love is as deadly a trio as has ever existed in the NBA. Another year to mesh, and the continued growth of Timofey Mozgov and Tristan Thompson, makes the Cavs the class of the East.
Photo: Ezra Shaw /Getty Images 2. Cleveland Cavaliers
Record: 53-29
Injuries derailed what may have... Image 30 of 31 1. Golden State Warriors
Record: 67-15
The reigning champs lost only David Lee from their rotation, but the entire starting lineup remains intact. Klay Thompson and Steph Curry form, once again, the greatest shooting backcourt in NBA history. Draymond Greene and Andrew Bogut provide a perfect mixture of fortitude and, for the opponent, annoyance. Harrison Barnes continues to improve and Finals MVP Andre Iguodala proved that, sometimes, a role player is far more than his title suggests.
Photo: Ezra Shaw, Staff / Getty Images 1. Golden State Warriors
Record: 67-15
The reigning champs lost only... Image 31 of 31 Spurs ranked No. 3 in ESPN power rankings 1 / 31 Back to Gallery ESPN released its initial NBA power rankings, placing the Golden State Warriors at the top of the mountain.
Rounding out the top five are Cleveland, San Antonio, the Los Angeles Clippers and Oklahoma City Thunder.
Down at the very bottom of the dregs are the Philadelphia 76ers, mired in a long and futile slump supposedly part of what general manager Sam Hinkie calls the "Process."
Click through the slideshow to see where ever NBA team ranks as we near the start of the 2015-2016 season.
nrmoyle@express-news.net
Twitter: @NRMoyle
